title: How to Add Mixed Numbers Together

steps.title: Add the whole numbers together.
steps.content: Add the whole numbers together. The whole numbers are 1 and 2, so 1+2 =3. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Find the lowest common denominator (LCD) of both fractions.
steps.content: Find the lowest common denominator (LCD) of both fractions. [2] X Research source The LCD is the lowest number that is evenly divisible by both numbers. [3] X Research source One way to find the LCD is just to write out the multiples of each denominator and see where they match for the first time. Since the denominators of the fractions are 2 and 4, the LCD is 4, because 4 is the smallest number that is divisible by both 2 and 4. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Convert the fractions to have the LCD as their denominator.
steps.content: Convert the fractions to have the LCD as their denominator. Before you can add the fractions, they have to have 4 as their denominator, so you have to make the fractions maintain their value while having a new base. Here's how to do it: Since the denominator of the fraction 1/2 has to be multiplied by 2 to get 4 as the new base, you should multiply the numerator 1 by 2 as well. 1x2=2, so the new fraction is 2/4. The fraction 2/4 = 1/2, but has been put in a larger ratio to have a larger base. This means that the numbers are equivalent fractions. They have a different base, but their value remains the same. [5] X Research source Since the fraction 3/4 already has the base of 4, you don't have to change it.

steps.title: Add the fractions.
steps.content: Add the fractions. Once you have a common denominator, the fractions can be added by simply adding the numerators. [6] X Research source 2/4 + 3/4 = 5/4

steps.title: Convert any improper fractions into mixed numbers.
steps.content: Convert any improper fractions into mixed numbers. An improper fraction is a fraction where the numerator is equal to or larger than the denominator. You need to convert the improper fraction into a mixed number before you can add it to the sum of the whole numbers. Since the original problem used mixed numbers, your answer should use mixed numbers too. Here's how to do it: [7] X Research source First, divide the numerator by the denominator. Do long division to divide 4 into 5. 4 goes into 5 1 time. This means that the quotient is 1. The remainder, or the number that is left over, is 1. Make your quotient the new whole number. Take your remainder and place it over the original denominator to finish converting the improper fraction into a mixed number. The quotient is 1, the remainder is 1, and the original denominator was 4, so the final answer is 1 1/4.

steps.title: Add the sum of the whole numbers and the sum of the fractions.
steps.content: Add the sum of the whole numbers and the sum of the fractions. To get your final answer, you have to add the two sums you found. 1 + 2 = 3 and 1/2 + 3/4 = 1 1/4, so 3 + 1 1/4 = 4 1/4. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Convert the mixed numbers into improper fractions.
steps.content: Convert the mixed numbers into improper fractions. You can do this by multiplying the denominator and whole number of a mixed number, and then adding this to the numerator of the fraction of the mixed number. [9] X Research source Your answer will be the new numerator while the denominator remains the same. [10] X Research source To convert 1 1/2 to a mixed number, multiply the whole number 1 by the denominator 2, and then add it to the numerator. Put your new answer over the original base. 1 * 2 = 2, and 2 + 1 = 3. Place the answer 3 over the original denominator and you have 3/2. To convert 2 3/4 to a mixed number, multiply the whole number 2 by the denominator 4. 2 * 4 = 8. Next, add this number to the original numerator and place it over the original denominator. 8 + 3 = 11. Put 11 over 4 to get 11/4.

steps.title: Find the lowest common multiple (LCM) of both the denominators.
steps.content: Find the lowest common multiple (LCM) of both the denominators. The LCM is the lowest number that is evenly divisible by both numbers. [11] X Research source If the denominators are already the same, skip this step. If one of the denominators is divisible by the other, the larger denominator is the LCM. The LCM of 2 and 4 is 4 because 4 is evenly divisible by 2.

steps.title: Make the denominators the same.
steps.content: Make the denominators the same. You can do this by finding equivalent fractions. Multiply the denominator by a number that will give you the LCM as the product. [12] X Research source Multiply the numerator by the same number. Do this with both fractions. Since the denominator of 3/2 has to be multiplied by 2 to get the new denominator of 4, you should multiply the numerator by 2 to find the equivalent fraction of 3/2. 3 * 2 = 6, so the new fraction is 6/4. Since 11/4 already has the denominator of 4, you're in luck. You don't have to change it.

steps.title: Add the two fractions.
steps.content: Add the two fractions. Now that the denominators are the same, just add the numerators to get your answer while keeping the same base. [13] X Research source 6/4 + 11/4 = 17/4.

steps.title: Convert the improper fraction back into a mixed fraction.
steps.content: Convert the improper fraction back into a mixed fraction. Since the original problem was in mixed number form, you can convert it back into a mixed number. [14] X Research source Here's how to do it: [15] X Research source First, divide the numerator by the denominator. Divide 4 into 17. 4 goes into 17 4 times, so the quotient is 4. The remainder, or the number that is left over, is 1. Make your quotient the new whole number. Take your remainder and place it over the original denominator to finish converting the improper fraction into a mixed number. The quotient is 4, the remainder is 1, and the original denominator was 4, so the final answer is 4 1/4.
